articles.headline: China Showers Myanmar With Attention, as Trump Looks Elsewhere
articles.snippet: Myanmar’s opening had been considered an American victory, but Beijing is bringing it into its fold with money and diplomacy.
articles.abstract: Myanmar’s opening had been considered an American victory, but Beijing is bringing it into its fold with money and diplomacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar — When Myanmar’s leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, wanted to hold a peace conference to end her country’s long-burning insurgencies, a senior Chinese diplomat went to work.

articles.headline: HNA Finds Wall St.’s Enthusiasm for Chinese Conglomerates Is Cooling
articles.snippet: The big American bank is walking away for now because it said it was concerned about the HNA’s structure, ownership and complex model.
articles.abstract: The big American bank is walking away for now because it said it was concerned about the HNA’s structure, ownership and complex model.
articles.lead_paragraph: HNA Group says that Wall Street’s biggest banks are knocking at the door to do business with it as the huge Chinese conglomerate buys up businesses around the globe.

articles.headline: Freddie Mac Follows Fannie Mae to Rental Market, With Affordability as Goal
articles.snippet: Unlike its mortgage finance counterpart, which agreed this year to a financing deal for a large private-equity-backed landlord, Freddie Mac is focused on midsize owners of rentals.
articles.abstract: Unlike its mortgage finance counterpart, which agreed this year to a financing deal for a large private-equity-backed landlord, Freddie Mac is focused on midsize owners of rentals.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the government-controlled mortgage finance giant Fannie Mae agreed this year to guarantee a $1 billion financing deal for one of the biggest private-equity-backed landlords in the United States, the move prompted an outcry.

articles.headline: Citing Recusal, Trump Says He Wouldn’t Have Hired Sessions
articles.snippet: The president also said in an interview that Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, would cross a red line if he delved into Trump family finances unrelated to Russia.
articles.abstract: The president also said in an interview that Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel, would cross a red line if he delved into Trump family finances unrelated to Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Wednesday that he never would have appointed Attorney General Jeff Sessions had he known Mr. Sessions would recuse himself from overseeing the Russia investigation that has dogged his presidency, calling the decision “very unfair to the president.”
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: John McCain Has Brain Cancer, Senator’s Office Says
articles.snippet: The medical condition was discovered after the Arizona senator underwent a procedure to remove a blood clot above his left eye.
articles.abstract: The medical condition was discovered after the Arizona senator underwent a procedure to remove a blood clot above his left eye.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator John McCain, the 2008 Republican presidential nominee known for his independent streak over more than three decades representing Arizona in the Senate, has brain cancer, his office disclosed Wednesday night in a statement from the Mayo Clinic.

articles.headline: Big German Bank, Key to Trump’s Finances, Faces New Scrutiny
articles.snippet: Regulators are reviewing loans from Deutsche Bank, which is also expecting to have to share information with the authorities investigating campaign ties to Russia.
articles.abstract: Regulators are reviewing loans from Deutsche Bank, which is also expecting to have to share information with the authorities investigating campaign ties to Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: During the presidential campaign, Donald J. Trump pointed to his relationship with Deutsche Bank to counter reports that big banks were skeptical of doing business with him.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Jesse Drucker

articles.headline: Easy Money Saved This Italian City. Soon, It Will Run Out.
articles.snippet: Pistoia’s train factory benefited from the European Central Bank’s bond buying program, which is drawing to a close.
articles.abstract: Pistoia’s train factory benefited from the European Central Bank’s bond buying program, which is drawing to a close.
articles.lead_paragraph: PISTOIA, Italy — As Europe’s era of easy money slowly draws to a close, the talk in Frankfurt and London is of bond yields, exchange rates and core inflation. In this medieval city at the foot of the Apennines, it’s all about trains.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Gaia Pianigiani

articles.headline: O.J. Simpson Wins Parole, Claiming He Has Led a ‘Conflict-Free Life’
articles.snippet: Mr. Simpson will be released in October after spending nine years in prison on charges stemming from an armed robbery.
articles.abstract: Mr. Simpson will be released in October after spending nine years in prison on charges stemming from an armed robbery.
articles.lead_paragraph: He has tumbled in the public eye from revered football hero and actor, to reviled wife abuser and murder defendant, to indebted and hapless convicted robber, but O.J. Simpson went before a Nevada parole board on Thursday flashing his usual self-assurance, telling the board that he was “a good guy” and asserting, implausibly, “I basically have spent a conflict-free life.”

articles.headline: Tax Reform, Reagan Style, May Be a Tougher Fit for Trump
articles.snippet: Some elements of the 1986 success are absent, like the number of remaining loopholes, and this president has a personal interest in those that remain.
articles.abstract: Some elements of the 1986 success are absent, like the number of remaining loopholes, and this president has a personal interest in those that remain.
articles.lead_paragraph: With efforts to reshape health care seemingly in shambles, Congress now confronts an issue that business-minded Republicans (and many Democrats) really care about: tax reform.

articles.headline: Trump’s Fury Erodes His Relationship With Sessions, an Early Ally
articles.snippet: Jeff Sessions, who angered the president when he recused himself from the Justice Department’s Russia investigation, said he intended to remain attorney general “as long as that is appropriate.”
articles.abstract: Jeff Sessions, who angered the president when he recused himself from the Justice Department’s Russia investigation, said he intended to remain attorney general “as long as that is appropriate.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s staff is used to his complaints about Attorney General Jeff Sessions, but the Republican senators who attended a White House dinner on Monday were stunned to hear him criticize the man who was once Mr. Trump’s most loyal supporter in the Senate.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Beijing Wants A.I. to Be Made in China by 2030
articles.snippet: A new plan from the top of the Chinese government calls for the country to become a powerhouse in artificial intelligence in just over a decade.
articles.abstract: A new plan from the top of the Chinese government calls for the country to become a powerhouse in artificial intelligence in just over a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — If Beijing has its way, the future of artificial intelligence will be made in China.

articles.headline: Israeli Aid Gives an Unexpected ‘Glimmer of Hope’ for Syrians
articles.snippet: Israel has been sending in truckloads of supplies and treating thousands of sick and wounded Syrians, denting its reputation in Syria as “the devil who wants to kill us.”
articles.abstract: Israel has been sending in truckloads of supplies and treating thousands of sick and wounded Syrians, denting its reputation in Syria as “the devil who wants to kill us.”
articles.lead_paragraph: GOLAN HEIGHTS — Quietly, over the last year, hundreds of sick Syrian children and their chaperones have been whisked across enemy lines at dawn for treatment at clinics in Israel, slipping back home after dark.
